Global and Transcultural Images and Screen Studies Interaction and Social Processes Persuasion and Politics Technology and Society              MCC-UE 1013 - Political Communication        This course focuses on the essentially communicative aspects of American governing processes, surveying research that analyzes the way in which political candidates at various levels of government are chosen, how they shape their personal image, the process of constructing persuasive message appeals, and their interaction with voters. It will also focus on how elected officials set political and legislative agendas, use public relations strategies to shape public policy, and otherwise engage in the process of political deliberation. The media in which these processes take place will be an additional focus, including the influence of news outlets, political campaign advertising, and the work of political advocacy groups of various kinds. Common methods utilized in political communication research will also be highlighted, including experimental and survey research, and various forms of textual analysis. Al Tamimi, AlHanouf   AlHanouf was born and raised in Kuwait City, Kuwait. As a resident in the Middle East coming from a family of well-known public figures, she was exposed to various forms of media and censorship, which then influenced her to pursue a degree in communications and media. During the summer of 2014, she graduated with a B.A. in Mass Communication and Media and a minor in Social and Behavioral Sciences with a concentration in Anthropology, as she wanted to focus on media and its influence on different cultures and societies worldwide. While at the American University in Kuwait, she had various opportunities whereby she immersed herself into the world of mass communications and media from working at a popular local brand and handling their public relations, social media, and online website to handling the stay of Steve Wozniak when he was in Kuwait to talk to young entrepreneurs. Opportunities as such helped prepare her mentally to what she will be expecting in the future in terms of her career. It also opened her eyes to the role of media within society, the rapid growth of social media, how technology affects media, and how media can alter the minds of many when it comes to politics and social movements.    AlHanouf plans to pursue her MA in MCC with an interest in human rights, citizenship, political communication and media and the idea of cross-cultural communication worldwide. This will ultimately allow her to create cross-cultural and political awareness in her society, and allow for an open door to new possibilities and ways of thinking in relation to communications and media back home. She plans to pursue a number of classes to further her knowledge in the field of Media, Culture and Communication. AlHanouf plans to follow an academic career path with a PhD program in the future.          Gilberg, Daniel   Danny graduated Vassar College in 2010 with a degree in history. After graduating, he spent a year as an AmeriCorps member at City Year, Washington DC. There, he worked as a reading and math tutor for two different first grade classrooms, and also organized after school activities. Since starting the MCC program, Danny has interned at various organizations in New York, including CBS News and the Clinton Foundation.    Danny’s coursework and research focuses primarily on the intersection of pop culture and American politics. His research projects have included the banning of books in public schools and the historical roots of the white savior complex in film. His Master's Thesis explores the television series Survivor and theories of politics and democracies that are embedded in the show's format. The project examines various domestic policies that have been proposed and/or enacted in the past decade and how it is reflected in the contestants' strategic game play.          Goldfond, Joshua   Focusing on Political & Persuasion and Interaction & Social Processes. Joshua graduated summa cum laude from Rutgers College, with a focus on English, History, and Film. He has spent the last decade working in entertainment media while pursuing a number of creative projects, including the production of several short films, the sale of a feature-length script, and the publication of a fantasy/satire novel called "The Hunting of the Bubblenuff”, which was well received by Kirkus Reviews. He currently runs an Arts & Culture website called "The Oculus Online," which features a variety of interviews and essays.    Josh wishes to investigate the concept of public manipulation and its emerging relationship with social media and corporate communications. It is clear that the technology of our age allows information to spread over distances and across cultures like never before. But will we find an ideological common ground as all peoples are exposed to all ideas? Or, will we become more Balkanized as we immerse ourselves in the culture, politics, and scientific interpretations of our preferred realities? In either case, what are the styles and methodologies of communication that will remain effective, rising above the noise and breaching the walls? Are there any sophisticated universal concepts left, or will the ammunition of tomorrow's messaging wars be LOL Cats? If so, which ones? He is also interested in "greenwashing," human rights violations, the rising gap between rich and poor, and similar such things that go bump in the night.          Quellhorst, Megan   Megan Quellhorst is a first-year student focusing on persuasion and politics. Prior to studying at NYU, she worked as a freelance associate producer for WNYC’s public radio show The Takeaway, where she produced global and national news stories and developed a variety of in-depth coverage series on topics such as healthcare reform and how the millennial generation relates to organized religion.    Previously, she was active in state government and politics in Ohio, where she worked as a field organizer for the congressional campaign of Mary Jo Kilroy, organizing voter outreach and education for Ohio State University and the surrounding area, and later served as the director of scheduling for Ohio Lt. Governor Lee Fisher.    Her internship experiences include the office of U.S. Senator Sherrod Brown, Governor Ted Strickland’s offices of Global Affairs and Constituent Services, and a health initiative fellowship in Cameroon, Africa. She graduated magna cum laude from Ohio State University with a B.A. in political science and a minor in international relations.    Broadly, Megan’s academic and research interests include representations of gender and race in the news media, strategic and political communication, and new media.          Sun, Lin   Born and raised in China, Lin graduated from the University of Iowa in 2013, with a B.A. in Communication Studies and a B.B.A. in Marketing. During college, she discovered her interest on digital media’s role in society and democracy, and decided to further her exploration on the topic at NYU. More specifically, she would like to investigate how social media influences social movements. Previously, Lin has been active in the communication industry. She has worked at Publicis Advertising and the University of Iowa’s marketing department. She was also a member of the PRSSA (Public Relations Student of America). Lin wishes to gain more experience in the industry, as she loves the strategic and creative work and believes such experiences will also nurture her research.          Zhang, Yi   Yi was raised in Beijing, China. She graduated from University of Minnesota in 2013 with a BA in economics. After the memorable four-year college life past, Minnesota is like the second homeland to her. She will going to attend the NYU’s MCC program fall 2014 to pursue a MA concentrating persuasion and politics area. Yi is interested in the interaction of business and media. After graduation, Yi was back to China and started to learn and gain experience from media industry. Her first internship was in Beijing television where she learned how television business works, then she interned with a PR company for luxuries. She intends to develop her career goal into fashion related field.                    This site, and all its contents, are Copyright ©    by New York University. All rights reserved.
